awd_abstract_narration:
Pathways to Mathematics (PTM) is a collaborative program between the University of South Alabama Colleges of Education, Arts & Sciences, and Engineering, Bishop State Community College, and the Mobile County Public Schools System (MCPSS). PTM is addressing the need to increase the number of mathematics teachers in the MCPSS through enabling recent mathematics and engineering bachelor degree graduates to complete secondary mathematics certification in an intensive four-semester program that culminates with certification and an earned master's degree. The newly certified teachers (Noyce Scholars) are then participating in a two-year post-employment mentoring program designed to provide classroom support after graduation. 

PTM is preparing a total of up to 25 mathematics teachers (over the five-year period) certified to teach mathematics at the secondary level. PTM is doubling the number of math teachers who earn their certification from the University of South Alabama by creating a pipeline of undergraduate students beginning at the community college level and culminating in an earned master's degree and certification in secondary mathematics education. This project is expected to enhance middle and high school student achievement by providing certified mathematics teachers in high needs schools that currently lack certified math teachers.

por.por_cntn:
The Noyce Pathway to Mathematics Program at the University of South Alabama exceeded its program goals by adding 26 master level mathematics teachers to local and nationwide faculties to teach students in grades 6-12. Of those who completed the program, 21 are still teaching in P-12 settings, three have returned to graduate school to study mathematics education that they might become teacher educators. Graduates have participated in conferences at the local and national level. Two graduates returned to industry, but they fulfilled their agreement with Noyce and taught additional years beyond their agreement. Those currently in the classroom serve as mentor teachers to preservice teachers from the institution. Two of the graduates are named as consultants on the newly awarded Pathway to Mathematics 2 Noyce award; one is a high school teacher and the other a middle school teacher. Both are hosting pre-residency students in their classrooms who are deciding whether they want to pursue the PTM 2 graduate program to attain a master’s degree in mathematics education and Alabama state teacher certification. The new award also includes participation in summer professional development institutes for new PTM 2 scholars and graduates of the PTM program. Program participants in PTM took part in Reacher Opportunities for Noyce Alumni wherein they learned how to incorporate Team Based Learning into their classrooms. They have participated in the partner grants hosting the Southeastern Noyce Regional Conference, as presenters, hosts, and coordinators. The outlook for their continued participation is positive, as many have taken advantage of the opportunity to become National Board Certified and National STEM Certified as part of the Alabama TEAMS initiative, and through the support of our regional inservice center and the Noyce projects at the University of South Alabama, all who submitted their portfolios have been successful in attaining this advanced certification.  


Last Modified: 12/01/2023
Modified by: Susan Ferguson
